text: ah so hello everyone my name is Meg
Kajal I am a software developer at
Schlumberger and I am a woman I have
been working in the software industry
for over 15 years so that means that I
have had a lot of conversations about
gender and software about how do we
encourage women and girls to pursue STEM
careers and stem programs and most
recently the me2 movement and in the
wake of the me2 movement I've actually
had a lot of my male colleagues who
started coming up to me and asking me
questions they're asking things like am
i doing something wrong
or have I done something wrong and
really what they want to know is are
they contributing to this bigger problem
and in large part no they're absolutely
fine but it got me thinking about all of
my experiences across my career and all
of the different teams that I've worked
on and I've been very lucky I've worked
on some amazing teams and I've worked
with some fantastic people but I've
started to notice that there are a few
things that tend to make my transition
into a new team awkward and I've been on
teams that have quite a few women and
I've been on teams that have very few or
no women and so I wanted to talk today
about some of those things that that
just make that transition into a new
team especially as a woman a little bit
more awkward and that way we can get rid
of them so the first thing is don't
panic chances are that if there's you're
probably not going to get pulled into a
sexual harassment lawsuit without
realizing that you were doing something
egregiously wrong and even if you are
desperately afraid of women you think
they're terrifying you don't know how to
talk to them well guess what when a
woman joins your software team you
already have one thing in common you
both work in software and you both work
on the same team so you already have
some common ground however even the best
intentions can sometimes go awry
and there are a few little behaviors and
a few little things that just don't
always play off the way you're expecting
them to and those are the things that I
wanted to talk about today and the first
one is to be careful of the spotlight so
one of the things that happens nearly
every time I join a team that doesn't
have any other women on it is someone
says something along the lines of hey
it's great that we finally have a woman
on our team or if there's only one woman
on the team already they'll say
something like oh I'm sure that Jane is
super excited to have another girl on
the team and these are always
well-intentioned basically what the
person is trying to say is they're
saying oh we value diversity and we're
glad that we have a new perspective and
that kind of thing but what they're
inadvertently doing is they're saying
you are different than we are and
already there's kind of an
us-versus-them mentality because you're
new to the team you are already the them
and they are the us and you are trying
to become part of the US and they're
saying oh wait no there's a second us
versus them play here you are a woman
and you are different than we are so
even though it's well-intentioned
it kind of comes off uttering and it
makes it puts you on the spot and it
makes you just a little bit
uncomfortable another thing that happens
is that people start to police their
language a little bit more so something
that would normally come out completely
natural like alright let's get to work
guys and girls and it's kind of that
after that afterthought is basically
putting a big spotlight on that
difference again and you know again it's
with the best intentions they mean to
say you know oh we're being inclusive
but really they're singling you out so
it's just something that happens from
time to time and it's not a big deal and
I'm glad that the deal the issues that I
deal with are not big deals but it's
just one of those little things that you
know if we stop and think about it maybe
we can stop doing those things and make
it a little bit less awkward
another thing is the there's always one
assumption that I face more
any other and that is that I was hired
for a quota or that I was hired to
improve diversity statistics and this is
extremely frustrating but it's been part
of my career for my entire life and when
I join a team where they don't already
know me and they don't already know my
skill set or my reputation people always
or not all people but many people tend
to question am I do I really have the
right to be there and it's become such a
problem that I actually found myself as
soon as I join a new team I try to find
a really challenging technical problem
or a really specific detail that I can
use to demonstrate my knowledge and
basically to prove to my new teammates
that I actually belong there so that
they will start to take me seriously and
that in itself is a problem but what's
also a problem is that I found that I
started to do the same thing because
this is the way I was being treated this
is the way I started treating other
people so I would have a new person come
and join a team that I'd been on for a
while and I would subconsciously be
thinking mmm do they really know what
they're doing I don't know let's find
out I'm not so sure and I wasn't
trusting my new colleagues the same way
that my previous new colleagues hadn't
been trusting me and when I realized
that I was doing that I decided that
this was something I wanted to
consciously work on so now when I have a
new team member joined my team I make a
specific effort to believe the best in
them like I am going to assume that you
know what you're doing and I will give
you responsibility along those veins and
I will ask you to do something and so
I've tried to adopt what I consider a
trust but verify mentality so I trust
that you know what you're doing but
before we put it into production I'm
going to make sure another kind of
assumption is stereotypes and there are
a lot of stereotypes about gender there
are a lot of stereotypes about women and
of course when you are a minority in an
industry you hear things about oh well
women are such an
and girls don't like this and you know
you're probably not good at that and of
course we all know that these
stereotypes are problematic they're
often wrong but even beyond that I
realized that this is actually an
especially important issue for other
women because even though we know that
there are all of these stereotypes about
women that don't necessarily hold for
women who work in technology and women
who work in computing we have our own
set of stereotypes I'm back in 2010
Mattel put out a computer engineer
Barbie as part of this whole encouraging
young girls to go into STEM careers and
that computer engineer Barbie had all
kinds of problems on its own with the
material they put out around it but when
I first saw I looked at it and I said oh
she doesn't look anything like a
computer engineer because this is what
computer engineer Barbie looked like and
I said about doing a Photoshop makeover
to turn her into what a computer
engineer looks like and this got all
kinds of traction and people were like
yes you're totally spot-on and a few
years later I realized that no I wasn't
because that isn't necessarily what a
computer engineer looks like she doesn't
need to be wearing a geeky t-shirt to be
good at her job I changed her hair I
changed well okay maybe the operating
system and the development environment
although she's a badass because she is
coding in binary but yeah I was
basically I was perpetuating our own
stereotype so now we're saying that
women who don't fit into the women in
tech stereotype are not necessarily
right for the industry and that's wrong
in itself so one of the things that I
went into before I came to give this
talk was I was debating about what to
wear and sometimes I wear a dress to
work and sometimes I wear a geeky
t-shirt to work but when I come to a
conference I always wear a geeky t-shirt
because so often people assume that I
work in HR or that I work in management
so I kind of wanted to wear that on my
chest I am a developer talk to me about
development things and so for this talk
I made a conscious decision to get out
of my comfort zone and wear something
that I
where to work but not into a setting
where people don't know me I swear I'm a
programmer even though I'm not wearing
it on my chest and another thing is that
not all women have the same ideas and
the same opinions about things so coming
back to the hey guys and girls thing for
me this this is always a stumbling block
because I grew up in the Midwestern u.s.
and where I grew up we use guys as a
gender-neutral pronoun so hey do you
guys want to go to the beach and that
could be a group of girls but that's
just the word that we use for the plural
of you because you versus you is
confusing
so we say you guys and it gets very
confusing when you go into the
possessive because you end up with you
guys's is this you guys this table it's
very confusing but for me guys is is a
gender neutral now or pronoun but I have
to remember that that's my upbringing
and that's my background and that's how
I feel about things so when we have new
women joining our team you know maybe I
have to step back and say oh well this
is the way I see things but is this the
way she thinks eats things so that
brings me to my last point which is if
you aren't sure about something just ask
that's the simplest solution and again
maybe do it privately don't do it in
front of a big group like hey you guys
oh is it okay if I say guys just take it
offline in a private conversation and
discuss it and find out how she feels
about a certain situation whether it's a
problem or not the other thing about
this is that it actually gives us a
chance to reevaluate ourselves so when
we when somebody comes to you and asked
you a question like this when my male
colleagues came and said are we doing
something wrong it made me stop and
think about it and it was only when I
stop to think about it from their
perspective of am i doing something
wrong did I start to see the things that
I was doing wrong so that catalyst
basically has improved my own awareness
of how I treat other women in software
as well as giving them a chance to
discuss their issues and hopefully if we
can overcome some of these things
we ever solved the bigger problem of how
do we get women into software just maybe
we can make it comfortable enough that
they'll stay so thank you very much
[Applause]
